title: Edit Service Level Agreement record
content:
Any Service Level Agreement can change over time as new services, processes, and equipment impact the agreement. You can update a Service Level Agreement record by changing any field in the form.

You can edit multiple records simultaneously by selecting them in the grid and updating them in the Preview pane on the right. For more information, see Mass update section under Update multiple records using the Preview pane topic.

  1. From the main menu, select Plan > Service Level.

  2. To edit a Service Agreement, select Service Agreements. To edit a Support Agreement, select Support and Case Agreements. To edit a Human resources Agreement, select Human Resources Agreements.

  3. Select the record you want to edit.

    To filter the record list, click the Add filter button. For more information, see Filter topic.

  4. Click the record identifier in the ID column to display the selected record.

  5. Edit any field in the General tab.

    Service Agreements
    Field Description
    Title 

    Type a word or phrase that's a unique identifier for this Service Level Agreement. Choose a value that helps the end user easily understand the purpose of the Service Level Target Set.

    Example: SLA for IT equipment orders.
    Type

    This field is read-only for existing agreements.
    Owner

    Choose the Service Level Agreement owner.

    Example: The owner can be the Service Level Manager.

    If no value is selected, the owner is set to the current user by default.
    Requirement Enter information related to any requirements associated with this Service Level Agreement, including cost, effort, and the dates for which the agreement is valid.
    Review and improvement Enter information to capture any review and improvement activities included in this Service Level Agreement, including the next review date, service quality report, improvement measures, and service improvement plan.
    Review and improvement Enter information to capture any review and improvement activities included in this Service Agreement, including the next review date, service quality report, improvement measures, and service improvement plan.
    Target Sets

    Do one of the following:

    • Click Add, then select a Service Level Target set to be linked to this Service Level Agreement.

    • Click the List icon to display available target sets. Select the check box for the one that you want to link to the Service Level Agreement. Click OK to select the linked target set.
      The selected target set appears in yellow. When you save the agreement, the linked target set is saved.

    • To remove a linked target set, select the target set and click Remove. The selected target set appears in strikethrough text. When you save the agreement, the linked target set is removed.

    For Service agreements, you can link target sets for Requests only.

    The list of available target sets includes only target sets with a matching module:

    • For Service SLAs, only target sets of module Service Request of type SLA are available.
    • For Service OLAs, only target sets of module Service Request of type OLA are available

    Note:

    • You can only select one target set to be linked to this Service Level Agreement.
    Support and Case Agreements
    Field Description
    Title 

    Type a word or phrase that is a unique identifier for this Service Level Agreement. Choose a value that helps the end user easily understand the purpose of the Service Level Target Set.

    Example: Initial review for priority 1 incidents.
    Type

    Select SLA to define a Service Level Agreement.

    Select OLA to define an Operational Level Agreement.

    This field is read-only for existing agreements.
    Default agreement

    Select the check box to set the Service Level Agreement as default. The default Service Level Agreement (for Incident, Support Request, Case Request, Change, Problem, or Task as appropriate) is automatically applied to all incidents, support requests, and case requests which do not match the Service Level Target Definition.
    Owner

    Choose the Service Level Agreement owner.

    Example: The owner can be the Service Level Manager.

    If no value is selected, the owner is set to the current user by default.
    Description Enter a description for the Service Level Agreement. This helps the other users understand the purpose and objectives of the Service Level Agreement.
    Requirement Enter information related to any requirements associated with the Service Level Agreement, including cost, effort, and the dates for which the agreement is valid.
    Review and improvement Enter information to capture any review and improvement activities included in the Service Level Agreement, including the next review date, service quality report, improvement measures, and service improvement plan.
    Services

    For Support requests and Case requests, in the Services section, do one of the following:

    • Click Add, then select an actual service to link the service to the Service Level Agreement.
    • Click the List icon to display available services. Select the checkbox for each item you want to link to the Service Level Agreement. Click OK to select the linked services.

    The selected services appear in yellow. When you save the agreement, the linked services are saved.

    To remove a linked service, select the service and click Remove. The selected services appear in strikethrough text. When you save the agreement, the linked services are removed.

    Although it is technically possible to configure more than 250 items, doing so exceeds the recommended threshold and may adversely impact system performance. To ensure optimal efficiency and stability, it is recommended to maintain the limit at 250.
    Target Sets

    Do one of the following:

    • Click Add, then select a Service Level Target sets to be linked to this Service Level Agreement.
    • Click the List icon to display available target sets. Select the checkbox for each item you want to link to the Service Level Agreement. Click OK to select the linked target sets.
      The selected target sets appear in yellow. When you save the agreement, the linked target sets are saved.

    • To remove a linked target sets, select the target sets and click Remove. The selected target sets appear in strikethrough text. When you save the agreement, the linked target sets are removed.

    For Support and Case Agreements, you can link target sets for Requests, Incidents, Changes, Tasks, Problems, and the customized record types created in Studio. For Service agreements, you can link target sets for Requests only.

    The list of available target sets includes only the target sets with a matching module:

    • For Support SLAs, the target sets of Type SLA with Incident, Support Request, Case Request, Change, Task, Problem, or customized record type selected as Module are available.
    • For Support OLAs, the target sets of Type OLA with Incident, Support Request, Case Request, Change, Task, Problem, or customized record type selected as Module are available.
    You can select multiple target sets to be linked to this Service Level Agreement, but the target sets selected must be with different Modules.

    For Support and Case Agreements, you can define a Service Level Agreement that does not identify a service. This type of Service Level Agreement can be useful as a default when you have similar services that do not require individual Service Level Agreements. To set it as a default, select the Default agreement check box.

    Human Resources Agreements
    Field Description
    Title 

    Type a word or phrase that is a unique identifier for this Service Level Agreement. Choose a value that helps the end user easily understand the purpose of the Service Level Target Set.

    Example: Initial review for priority 1 incidents.
    Type

    Select SLA to define a Service Level Agreement.

    Select OLA to define an Operational Level Agreement.

    This field is read-only for existing agreements.
    Default agreement Select the check box to set the Service Level Agreement as default. The default Service Level Agreement for HR Support Requests is automatically applied to all requests which do not match the Service Level Target Definition.
    Owner

    Choose the Service Level Agreement owner.

    Example: The owner can be the Service Level Manager.

    If no value is selected, the owner is set to the current user by default.
    Description Enter a description for the Service Level Agreement. This helps the other users understand the purpose and objectives of the Service Level Agreement.
    Requirement Enter information related to any requirements associated with the Service Level Agreement, including cost, effort, and the dates for which the agreement is valid.
    Review and improvement Enter information to capture any review and improvement activities included in the Service Level Agreement, including the next review date, service quality report, improvement measures, and service improvement plan.
    Target Sets

    Do one of the following:

    • Click Add, then select a Service Level Target set to be linked to this Service Level Agreement.
    • Click the List icon to display available target sets. Select the check box for each item you want to link to the Service Level Agreement. Click OK to select the linked target set.

    • Click the List icon to display available target sets. Select the check box for each item you want to link to the Service Level Agreement. Click OK to select the linked target set.
      The selected target sets appear in yellow. When you save the agreement, the linked target set is saved.

    • To remove a linked target set, select the target set and click Remove. The selected target set appear in strikethrough text. When you save the agreement, the linked target set is removed.

    For Human Resources agreements, you can only link target sets for Requests.

    The list of available target sets includes only target sets with a matching module:

    • For Human Resources SLAs, only target sets of module Service Request of type SLA are available.
    • For Human Resources OLAs, only target sets of module Service Request of type OLA are available.

    Note:

    • You can only select one target set to be linked to the Service Level Agreement.

  6. For Operational Level Agreements, you can edit the following fields in the Group target sets tab.

    Field Description
    Target Sets 

    The target set selected for the agreement is the same one selected in the Target Sets section in the General tab. You can select it from here also.

    The list of available target sets includes only target sets with a matching module:

    • For Support OLAs, only the target sets of Type OLA with Incident, Support request, Case request, Change, Task, Problem, or customized record type selected as Module are available.
    • For Service OLAs, only target sets of module Service Request of type OLA are available.
    Group override rules

    In the Group override rules section, you can define override rules to override the default target set for specified groups.

    • To add an override rule, click Add. In the New group override rule dialog box, enter the following information:

      • Name: Enter a name for the rule

      • Groups: Click in the Groups by name box to display a drop-down list of groups. Select the required groups to add.

        You cannot select the same group in more than one override rule in an agreement.

      • Target sets: Select the target sets. The target sets selected must be with a same Module.
        • For Support OLAs, only the target sets of Type OLA with Incident, Support request, Case request, Change, Task, Problem, or customized record type selected as Module are available.
        • For Service OLAs, only target sets of module Service Request of type OLA are available.
      • Click Save to save the rule.
    • To edit an override rule, select the required rule and click Edit.
    • To delete an override rule, select the rule and click Delete.

    The maximum number of target sets that can be added is 500.

  7. Click  Save on the toolbar.

You can click the History tab to view changes of the selected record. For more information about history, see History topic.
